node.text:
🍣 SUSHI WITH KIDS // Before you scroll past this post, because you think making sushi with your kids is too hard, STOP! 🛑 Let me tell you, it is totally doable and the results are deeelicious! 🤩 We used @gimmegrams sushi nori, which is restaurant-quality and organic! 🤤 Just watch the full video 📹 to see my 3 year old in action, and read on below👇 for the step-by-step instructions and some tips to make things as easy as possible! 🙌
-
💚 Sponsored 💚 
-
HERE’S WHAT YOU NEED
• 2 cups sushi rice cooked, we made ours in an instant pot!
• Rice Vinegar
• Sugar
• Salt
• gimMe Sushi Nori
• Sesame Seed
• Avocado
• Cucumber
• Imitation Crab
-
HOW TO
(1) Season the sushi rice to taste, we added about 1/4 cup vinegar, 1/2 tsp sugar, and 1 tsp salt;
(2) On top of a rolling mat, place one sheet of gimMe Sushi Nori (rough side up!);
(3) Spread the sushi rice on top in an even layer. (Wet your hands as needed!)
(4) Sprinkle sesame seeds on top of the rice;
(5) Flip the rice-covered nori over;
(6) On top of the nori, arrange slices of avocado, slices of cucumber, and imitation crab, leaving 1 inch of rice from the bottom.
(7) Roll the mat over, keeping the filling in place with your fingers, so that you make a tight log!
(8) Remove the rolling mat, and (grown ups!) use a sharp, wet knife to slice into pieces.
-
TIPS
• PREP THE MATERIALS: Having the items prepped will make the process run so much smoother.
-
• STICKY SOLUTION: The very nature of sushi rice is that it is sticky! Have plenty of dish towels and a bowl of water nearby to reset clean hands!
-
• SLICING THE SUSHI: My 3yo tried slicing the sushi with his kid-friendly knife, but it was not sharp enough to do the job! So have a grown-up do this part!
-

node.text:
If you have a picky eater (or as I like to say, a selective eater), then you know introducing new or different foods can be a challenge! 😅 But, oh. my. gosh! 😍 Here is an activity, that brought the fun back to our kitchen table! 🤩 We approached this experiment-style, noting exposure to a new food through sight, feel, and ultimately taste! 👅 I gave my selective eater 4 new foods to explore —  @gimmegrams seaweed, kiwi, pan de yuca, and sautéed carrots — and his exploration of each was absolutely amazing! 🙌 I’d love to know whether you’ll try this too! Or if you know a friend who this activity might benefit, be sure to share it with them! 👌 Any questions at all? Drop👇 them in the comment section below, or DM me!
-
#gimmepartner #gimmeseaweed

node.text:
This diy counting board is the perfect tactile resource for early math learning! 🤩 The removable cards and moveable wooden beads are perfect for some hands on fun. 🙌 While this craft certainly takes a little more effort to create than most of our activities, the good news is, it is a resource we come back to time and time again! 👌 Plus, it is super adaptable for children at different math levels as you can add as many beads as you like! 👍 Read on below👇for the how-to and if you have any questions at all, send me a direct message!
-
WHAT YOU’LL NEED
• 2 pieces of identical Cardboard, and additional cardboard for number cards
• Twine or thick string
• Beads
• Glue
• Hole punch
-
HOW TO
(1) Using a sharp knife, cut out 2 rectangular shapes on one of the cardboard pieces. This is where the number cards will go.
(2) Then cut out a thin, long rectangle below. This is where the tactile counting beads will go.
(3) Punch a hole on each end of the rectangle;
(4) Tie a piece of twine through one hole securely;
(5) Thread the beads onto the twine and secure the beads by tying the other end to the hole;
(6) Glue the 2 cardboard pieces together, with the beads and cut out pieces on the top;
(7) Take scrap cardboard, and cut out rectangle shapes for the number cards;
(8) On each rectangle, write each number. If counting to 20, you’ll need two 1s. If counting to 30, you’ll need an additional two 2s, and so forth. Now the board is ready for some serious counting fun!
-

node.text:
Who else has set up an activity only to have your kiddo not want anything to do with it? 😅 Well, this is your weekly reminder that this is totally normal and to not get discouraged! 👌 It happens in this house all the time. 🙃 Every child is different. And not all children learn the same things at the same time in the same way. Where one child will happily complete a worksheet, ✍️ another child may need a more tactile hands-on experience. 🤲 Where one child refuses a sensory-based activity one day, don’t be surprised if there is interest the next time it is set up. 🙌 No doubt, every child has the potential to learn it’s just not one-size fits all! ✨
-
Share this with a friend who may need to see it today!
-

node.text:
DIY catapults are a blast! ✨ And all you need are a few household items — popsicles sticks, rubber bands, and bottle tops. 🙌 Test out different angles and launching items - like pom poms, twigs and leaves! 👌 Read on below 👇 for the simple how to, and save this post so you don’t forget to do it later! Head to my stories for a how-to video for those who like the visual! 👀
-
MATERIALS
• 10 craft or popsicle sticks
• 4 rubber bands
• 1 bottle cap
• items to launch (like pom poms, rocks)
-
HOW TO
(1) Stack 8 craft sticks together and bind them with 2 rubber bands, one on each end.
(2) With the 2 remaining craft sticks, bind them at one end with a rubber band;
(3) Sandwich the stack of 8 craft sticks in between the stack of 2 craft sticks.
(4) Criss cross a rubber band around the sandwiched stack of craft sticks hold it it all in place; and
(5) Hot glue a bottle cap at the end of the topmost craft stick. Use it to place items like pom poms or rocks inside, pull back, and launch! Keep in mind that you may have to readjust the rubber bands as your child plays with this diy catapult!
-

In less than a week baby girl will be 3 years old! 🥳 It feels just like yesterday when I unveiled her footprint artwork to her and she had the most adorable reaction! 😍 (Check it out in stories). Creating this was super easy — just grab a print of baby’s feet each month for the first year, 🎨 place them next to each other or in a walking path like we did and enjoy seeing the incredible growth! 🤩Missed the first year? No problem! It’s never too late to start making handprint and footprint art - grab one this year, and do it the next year, and so on! 👌 Save this post so you don’t forget to do it! And share this with a friend who might want to do it too! 💕

node.text:
I have to admit this one is hard for me… finding the time to live in the moment. 😖 Who else is go go go all the time? 🏃‍♀️ Or are you able to slow down? 🧘‍♀️ Pre-kids, you’d bet I’d be all about that reading, and journal writing, and sipping that coffee while it was still hot! 😅 But kids and their constant needs, the piles of things always needing organizing and cleaning, and the schedules with their never ending cycle changed all that. Nope. I haven’t been good about slowing down at all. Which is why I needed to see this quote by @angelarepke. It’s such a good reminder of why it isn’t just important for my own mental health, but how important me modeling the slow-down-behavior is for my children’s future. 👌 Sure, I want them to be go-getters and motivated about all the things, but I also want them to enjoy the moment, to be present, to savor the now. Because it is gone way too fast. ⏳
-
Share this with a friend who may need to see it today!
-

node.text:
Wait! Don’t scroll past this before hearing me out. 🤗 You may think making dyed pasta is going to take too long and not worth the effort, but let me tell you, it is such an easy process! 😌 And the best part is it lasts SO LONG and can be used for SO MANY things! 👌 I’ve had this batch of rainbow penne for over a year and we’ve color sorted it, made necklaces, used it as art, practiced counting with it, threaded it on sticks, made a colorful sensory bottle, and so much more! 🙌Read on below 👇 for the easy how-to and don’t forget to save this post because I URGE you to make this some day, you won’t regret it! 💪
-
WHAT YOU’LL NEED
(1) White Vinegar
(2) Liquid Water Color or food coloring
(3) Pasta (4) Re-usable container with lid, or plastic bag with zipper
(5) Baking Sheet
(6) Wax Paper
-
HOW TO
(1) To make 6 different colors, first split up a 1 pound box of pasta (about 1/2 cup each);
(2) In a reusable container add 1 tsp white vinegar and 1 tbsp liquid water color or food coloring;
(3) Repeat for each color!
(4) On a baking sheet with wax paper, spread the pasta in a thin layer;
(5) After an hour of drying separate any pieces that may have stuck together;
(6) Allow to dry for several more hours or overnight.
-

node.text:
This is what complete and utter screen-free joy looks like! 🤩 For our latest travel this summer, this toy is one of my kid’s must-have items to bring along on our adventures! 💕 It’s called My Fabulous Storyteller by @lunii_us and it is a screen free way to not only listen to stories, but create them! 🎧 These aren’t just audio books, they are interactive, choose-your-own adventure style stories inside the cutest, lightweight yet durable device! Not to mention, they spark imaginations in incredible ways. 🙌 Best part for parents? They make long plane or car rides much more entertaining! 😅 Plus, you can also use it to create your own stories whether from your kiddo’s mouths themselves, or recorded by a family member or friend! 😯 Available at Target (swiping up in stories)! Share this with a friend who you think might want to know about this and head to my stories to see our Lunii in action!

node.text:
A budget friendly alphabet game using wooden spoons and a cardboard box. ♻️ It’s a fun hands on diy alternative to an alphabet puzzle. Adapt this based on your kiddo’s skill level - using lowercase letters, numbers, or even colors too! 👌 Plus, aiming the thin bases of the spoon through those small slots is great for hand eye coordination and fine motor skills in general! 🙌 Save this post so you remember to do it later and share it with a friend who might want to make it too! 💕
-
